intro: Secamone sansibariensis, commonly known as the East African secamone, is a flowering plant native to the coastal regions of East Africa. It belongs to the Apocynaceae family and is characterized by its woody stems and showy, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils along the shores and is adapted to coastal conditions. Its flowers are usually yellow or orange, and it produces small, fleshy fruits that contain seeds. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species in its native habitat.
